description: This notification is generated when the system
enters or leaves the Overload state. The number
of times this has be generated and cleared is kept
track of by ciiSysStatLSPDbaseOloads.

Summary.eval: ($v2 == 1) ? 'IS-IS is not active at $v1' : (($v2 == 2) ? 'IS-IS is active at this level $v1, and not overloaded' : (($v2 == 3) ? 'Database is low on an essential resource' : 'Database is overloaded'))

description: This notification is generated when one of the
manual areaAddresses assigned to this system is
ignored when computing routes. The object
ciiNotifManualAddress describes the area that
has been dropped.
The number of times this event has been generated
is counted by ciiSysStatManAddrDropFromAreas.
This notification is edge triggered, and should not
be regenerated until an address that was used in
the previous computation has been dropped.

event.Summary: $v1 has been ignored when computing routes

description: This notification is generated when we find that
an LSP that was stored in memory has become
corrupted. The number of times this has been
generated is counted by ciiSysStatCorrLSPs.
We forward an LSP ID. We may have independent
knowledge of the ID, but in some implementations
there is a chance that the ID itself will be
corrupted.

event.Summary: LSP stored in memory has become corrupted

description: When the sequence number on an LSP we generate
wraps the 32 bit sequence counter, we purge and
wait to re-announce this information. This
notification describes that event. Since these
should not be generated rapidly, we generate
an event each time this happens.
While the first 6 bytes of the LSPID are ours
the other two contain useful information.
A notification sent when we receive a PDU
with a different value of the System ID Length.
This notification includes an index to identify
the circuit where we saw the PDU and the header of
the PDU which may help a network manager identify
the source of the confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received on the same circuit.

event.Summary: Mismatch system ID length of $v3 detected on $v1

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiIDLenMismatch CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFieldLen u 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a PDU
with a different value of the Maximum Area
Addresses. This notification includes the
header of the packet, which may help a
network manager identify the source of the
confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: Mismatch on $v1 with Max Area Address of $v2

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiMaxAreaAddressesMismatch CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduMaxAreaAddress u 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a PDU
with our systemID and zero age. This
notification includes the circuit Index
and router ID from the LSP, if available
which may help a network manager
identify the source of the confusion.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiOwnLSPPurge CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE

description: When we receive an LSP with our System ID
and different contents, we may need to reissue
the LSP with a higher sequence number.
We send this notification if we need to increase
the sequence number by more than one. If two
Intermediate Systems are configured with the same
System ID, this notification will fire.

event.Summary: $v3 on $v1 has skipped ahead in sequence

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiSequenceNumberSkip CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE

description: A notification sent when we receive a PDU
with the wrong authentication type field.
This notification includes the header of the
packet, which may help a network manager
identify the source of the confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: $v1 indicated PDU recieved with incorrect authentication type field

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiAuthenticationTypeFailure CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a PDU
with incorrect authentication information
field. This notification includes the header
of the packet, which may help a network manager
identify the source of the confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: $v1 indicated PDU recieved with incorrect authentication information field

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiAuthenticationFailure CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a Hello
PDU from an IS running a different version
of the protocol. This notification includes
the header of the packet, which may help a
network manager identify the source of the
confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: $v1 indicated PDU is running different version of the protocol $v3

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiVersionSkew CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduProtocolVersion u 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a Hello
PDU from an IS which does not share any
area address. This notification includes
the header of the packet, which may help a
network manager identify the source of the
confusion.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: PDU does not share any area addresses

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiAreaMismatch CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we receive a Hello
PDU from an IS, but do not establish an
adjacency for some reason.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the circuit.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiRejectedAdjacency CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when we attempt to propagate
an LSP which is larger than the dataLinkBlockSize
for the circuit.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: $v1 has detected unable to propagate LSP due to larger dataLinkBlockSize ($v3) than the circuit

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiLSPTooLargeToPropagate CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspSize i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE

description: A notification sent when a Level 1 LSP or Level
2 LSP is received which is larger than the local
value for ciiSysLevelOrigLSPBuffSize, or when an
LSP is received containing the originatingLSPBufferSize
option and the value in the PDU option field does
not match the local value for ciiSysLevelOrigLSPBuffSize.
We pass up the size from the option field or the
size of the LSP that exceeds our configuration.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

event.Summary: $v1 detected buffer size of $v4 to be a mismatch for PDU LSP $v3

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiOrigLSPBuffSizeMismatch CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduOriginatingBufferSize u 9999

description: A notification sent when a non-pseudonode
segment 0 LSP is received that has no matching
protocols supported.
This may be because the system does not generate
the field, or because there are no common elements.
The list of protocols supported should be included
in the notification: it may be empty if the TLV
is not supported, or if the TLV is empty.
This should be an edge-triggered notification.
We should not send a second notification about
PDUs received from the same circuit.

Summary.eval: ($v3 ne '') ? '$v1 did not detect a matching protocol to the following : $v3' : '$v1 has detected no matching protocol supported'

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiProtocolsSupportedMismatch CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduProtocolsSupported s EXAMPLE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE

description: A notification sent when an adjacency changes
state, entering or leaving state up.
The first 6 bytes of the ciiPduLspId are the
SystemID of the adjacent IS.
The ciiAdjState is the new state of the adjacency.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiAdjacencyChange CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiAdjState i 1

description: This notification is generated when we receive
an LSP with a parse error. The ciiCircIfIndex
holds in index of the circuit on which the PDU
arrived. The ciiPduFragment holds start of the LSP
and the ciiErrorOffset points to the problem.
If the problem is a mal-formed TLV, ciiErrorOffset
points to start of the TLV and ciiErrorTLVType
holds the value of the type.
If the problem is with the LSP header, ciiErrorOffset
points to the suspicious byte.
The number of such LSPs is accumulated in
ciiSysStatLSPErrors.

event.Summary: $v1 has detect LSP was recieved with parse error

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiLSPErrorDetected CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiNotifIsLevelIndex i 1 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduLspId s EXAMPLEE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiCircIfIndex i 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiPduFragment s EXAMPLE CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiErrorOffset u 9999 CISCO-IETF-ISIS-MIB::ciiErrorTLVType u 9999
